title: Gene relevance based on multiple evidences in complex networks.
text: document describes R package mND (Di Nanni et al. 2019), new network diffusion based method integrative multi-omics analysis.

title: Gene relevance based on multiple evidences in complex networks.
text: package can installed within R: ##Input data package requires: adjacency matrix (\(\)) undirected interaction network \(G\); score matrix \(X0=[x_1, x_2, ..., x_L]\), column \(x_i\) (layer) represents score vector vertices \(G\). number top k-neighbour consider (\(k\)). Optional arguments : Number permutations (\(r\)) input matrix; Number cores (\(cores\)).
code: install.packages(c("devtools", "igraph", "parallel")) library(devtools) install_github("emosca-cnr/mND", build_vignettes = TRUE) library(mND)

title: Gene relevance based on multiple evidences in complex networks.
text: analysis can run using following functions: analyses can easily carried wrapper function framework_mND: ##Case study: integration mutation expression changes breast cancer proof principle, mND applied find functionally related genes basis gene mutations (\(L_1\)) gene expression variation (\(L_2\)) breast cancer (BC). Somatic mutations gene expression data matched tumour-normal samples (blood SM solid tissue GE) collected Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) (Tomczak et al. 2015) BC, using R package TCGAbiolinks (Colaprico et al. 2015) considering human genome version 38 (hg38). Mutation Annotation Format files obtained 4 pipelines: Muse (Fan et al. 2016), Mutect2 (Cibulskis et al. 2013), SomaticSniper (Larson et al. 2011), Varscan2 (Koboldt et al. 2012). mutation sites detected least two variant callers considered. Gene mutation frequencies (\(f\)) calculated fraction subjects gene associated least one mutation. Gene expression data obtained using TCGA workflow ``HTSeq-Counts’’. R package limma (Ritchie et al. 2015) used normalize quantify differential expression matched tumor-normal samples, yielding log-fold changes, corresponding p-values FDRs (BH method). Adjacency matrix (\(\)) undirected interaction network STRING (Szklarczyk et al. 2015) used; \(X0\) matrix defined two column vectors: \(x_1 = f\) \(x_2 = -log_{10}(FDR)\). can load \(X0\) \(\) follows: Let’s normalize adjacency matrix \(W\) create 50 permutations \(X0\). list X0_perm 51 elements, first input matrix \(X0\), others permutations; can load precomputed permutations using data(X0_perm), permutations obtained seed equal 2. Now, let’s apply network diffusion list X0_perm; can load precomputed diffused scores using data(Xs): Network-diffusion, quantifies network proximity gene altered genes (positive elements \(x_1\) \(x_2\)), transformed input vector \(x_1\) \(x_2\) \(x_1^*\) \(x_2^*\) respectively.  Let’s use function neighbour_index retrive list gene neighbours indexes adjacency matrix: Now, can apply mND function find functionally related genes basis \(x_1^*\) \(x_2^*\) top \(k\) neighbours; precomputed mND scores (calculated \(k = 3\)) included mND package data (.e. data(mND_score)). value \(k\) can optimised exploring effect values around 3 ranked gene list provided mND output (see optimize_k function). Empirical \(p\)-values calculated using pool \(r\) permutated versions \(X0\): Lastly, let’s classify genes every layer. define set high scoring genes : \(H_1\): genes mutation frequency greater zero; \(H_2\): top 1200 differentially expressed genes (FDR < \(10^-7\)). , set cardinalities gene sets \(N_1\) \(N_2\), containing genes highest scoring neighborhoods, \(|H_1|=|N_1|\) \(|H_2|=|N_2|\). summary previous results can obtained plot_results function, gives output following plots: genes ranked mND score corresponding p-value; gene networks composed top \(n\) ranking genes; gene classification top 100 ranking genes across layers; legend: brown: isolated; orange: linker; purple: module; grey: significant.  ###Optimization k value opportunity optimize value \(k\) relies selecting value yields connected networks enriched initial scores; optimize_k function can used objective. Let’s use optimize_k function create list mND scores calculated different \(k\) values (\(1 <= k <= 5\)) evaluate value \(k\) yields connected networks enriched initial scores. can load precomputed results using data(k_results). \(k = 3\) reasonable choice obtain connected gene networks enriched genes highest mutation frequencies expression variations.  ##References
code: W <- normalize_adj_mat(A) X0_perm <- perm_X0(X0, r = 50, W) Xs <- ND(X0_perm, W, cores = 4) ind_adj <- neighbour_index(W) mND_score <- mND(Xs, ind_adj, k = 3, cores = 4) mND_score <- signif_assess(mND_score) class_res <- classification(mND_score, X0, Hl, top, alpha) plot_results(mND_score, class_res, W, n = 150, directory = "~/mND_results") W <- normalize_adj_mat(A) mND_score <- framework_mND(X0, W, k = 3, r = 50, cores = 4) class_res <- classification(mND_score, X0, Hl, top, alpha) plot_results(mND_score, class_res, W, n = 150, directory = "~/mND_results") library(mND) data(X0) head(X0,3) #L1: mutations, L2: gene expression variations ##        L1        L2 ## FAM3C   0 0.5039283 ## VTI1B   0 2.3264157 ## MAGED2  0 3.1520429  data(A) #adjacency matrix of STRING itnteractome library(mND) W <- normalize_adj_mat(A) X0_perm <- perm_X0(X0, r = 50, W, seed_n = 2) library(mND) Xs <- ND(X0_perm, W, cores = 4) library(mND) ind_adj <- neighbour_index(W) library(mND) mND_score <- mND(Xs, ind_adj, k=3, cores = 4) library(mND) mND_score <- signif_assess(mND_score) library(mND) data(X0) Hl <- list(l1 = rownames(X0[X0[,1]>0,]),             l2 = names(X0[order(X0[,2], decreasing = T),2][1:1200]) ) top_Nl <- unlist(lapply(Hl, function(x) length(x))) top_Nl ##   l1   l2  ## 1238 1200  class_res <- classification(mND_score, X0, Hl, top = top_Nl)  #Classification of genes in every layer head(class_res$gene_class) ##        L1 L2 ## TP53    I  L ## TRIM28  M NS ## CCNB1   M  M ## RPS27A  M  L ## UBA52   M  L ## CCNA2   L  M  #Occurrence of (M; L; I; NS) for each gene across layers head(class_res$occ_labels) ##          I   L   M  NS ## TP53   0.5 0.5 0.0 0.0 ## TRIM28 0.0 0.0 0.5 0.5 ## CCNB1  0.0 0.0 1.0 0.0 ## RPS27A 0.0 0.5 0.5 0.0 ## UBA52  0.0 0.5 0.5 0.0 ## CCNA2  0.0 0.5 0.5 0.0 library(mND) plot_results(mND_score, class_res, W, n = 150, directory = "~/mND_results") library(mND)  k_val <- seq(1,5,1) k_results <- optimize_k(Xs, X0, k_val, ind_adj, W, top = 200, cores = 4)

what: Gene relevance based on multiple evidences in complex networks
title: Gene relevance based on multiple evidences in complex networks
text: mND uses multi-layer Network Diffusion find gene networks contain high scoring genes. considers two “layers” genome-wide scores interactome.  image : https://academic.oup.com/bioinformatics/article/36/3/865/5553095

title: Gene relevance based on multiple evidences in complex networks
text: use software, please cite: Di Nanni N, Gnocchi M, Moscatelli M, Milanesi L Mosca E, Gene relevance based multiple evidences complex networks, Bioinformatics, Volume 36, Issue 3, 1 February 2020, Pages 865–871, https://doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/btz652

title: mND global function — framework_mND

text: X0 matrix; column (layer) matrix X0 score vector vertices G. W matrix; symmetrically normalized adjacency matrix W = D^-1 D^-1, see 'normalize_adj_mat' function alpha numeric; smothing factor nMax numeric; maximum number iterations eps numeric; iteration stop maximum difference matrix Xs two consecutive iteraction smaller eps k numeric; number top k first neighbors r numeric; number permutations seed_n numeric; given 'seed_n' determine permutations X0 ensures reproducibility analysis cores numeric; number cores run parallel

title: mND global function — framework_mND

title: Plot results — plot_results

Legend: brown: isolated; orange: linker; purple: module; grey: significant.

title: Significance assessment — signif_assess
